div1.head: Letter from James E. Pilcher to Howard A. Kelly, November 30, 1908
div1.opener:
Association of Military Surgeons
of the United States
Major James Evelyn Pilcher.
Secretary and Editor
Carlisle, Pennsylvania, U.S.A.
November 30, 1908.
ans
12/1/08
Dictated No. 5.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
Baltimore, Md.
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Sir
My dear Dr. Kelley:-
div1.p:
Referring to our conversation of
Friday evening with regard to my old friend James
Carroll, I would say that I arrived at Fort Custer,
Mont., in the latter part of January 1884, almost at
the beginning of my own military service, and found
at the post hospital as Senior Hospital Steward a man
of about my own age in the person of James Carroll.
Carroll was at that time in appearance almost exactly
what he was when I last saw him about a year before
his death, for the years had apparently touched him
lightly up to almost the very last. We became very
friendly for I recognized in him qualities far above
those found in the ordinary enlisted man, and at his
request I undertook to start him upon the study of
medicine. The picture of the first lesson as we sat
in the surgeon's office in the hospital at Fort Custer,
discussing the occipital bone, is indelibly impressed
upon my memory; it was Carroll's first step in the
real study of medicine. Several months later he took
a long furlough with the purpose of proceeding to New
York and attending lectures--as we used to say in
those days--at a medical college. During that period
we corresponded and I was much pleased to see, upon
receipt of the college catalogue, in which his name
appeared, that he claimed me as his preceptor. I con-
tinued my interest in him and, as I told you Friday
evening, obtained for him a few years later, when he
had acquired the degree of M. D., a station at which,
although still an enlisted man, he would have been
practically Post Surgeon of one of the New York Harbor
posts--a post of which I was nominally surgeon, al-
though I resided upon another Island and in another
garrison. This however he declined in order to re-
main in Baltimore and prosecute his pathological

studies, so that it was not until the Spanish-American
War that I met him again. We met frequently after
that however, and I have in my possession a letter from
him, written in 1902 I think, after he had been commis-
sioned as a medical officer, in which he stated with
the exaggeration born of profound, although perhaps
undeserved appreciation, that all he had done he owed
to me.

This briefly is the story of the relations of
Carroll and myself, very baldly stated of course, for
there are many details both of character and incident
which I might give to illustrate the situation, but I
presume that the facts which I have mentioned will cov-
er the ground which you wish. In case anything else
should be desired or I can be of any further service
I trust you will command me.

closer.salute:
With kind regards,
Very cordially yours,
